div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,701] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, MARCH 4, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Swan Fountain Pen
div.p: Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about March 8
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about March 21.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said March 11
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said March 15

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th May.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 5,775 tons, leaves about March 14.
S.S. Shropshire 5,785 tons, leaves about March 17.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos March 6 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos March 8 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos March 19 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, March 11, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Tuesday 11th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: WHITE STAR LINE.
div.p: NEW YORK AND BOSTON MEDITERRANEAN SERVICE.

Regular Sailings between Alexandria , Naples, and Boston or New York, U.S.A. By the large modern twin screw steamers CELTIC, 21,000 tons- REPUBLIC, 15,400 tons- CANOPIC, 13,000 tons- ROMANIC, 11,400 tons.

Regular Service between Italy and United States throughout the year. Excellent accommodation for all classes of passengers. For plans of steamers, rates of passengers between the various ports, and full particulars, apply to THOS, COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor and Assouan; John Ross & Co., Alexandria; White Star Line, Via Roma, Gena, and 21, Piazza della Borsa, Naples.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus Line. Beyrout, Limassol, Larnaca, Mersina, Febr. 26; March 12, 26 ; April 9. 23 ; May 7, 21 ; June 4, 18.
Far East Lines. Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 6 March, 3 April, 4 May, 3 June.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service 22 Febr.; 7, 23 March ; 4, 23 April ; 8 May ; 8 June.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 18 Jan., 18 Feb., 18 March, 18 April, 18 May, 18 June. – For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, and Khartum.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

p.hi: Sold by local Chemists and Storekeepers.

div.head: JUST PUBLISHED
div.p: THE INDICATEUR EGYPTIEN
Administrative and Commercial Directory,
By
Mr. STEFANO POFFANDI
THE EDITION FOR 1907 contains up-to-date information which is absolutely reliable.
All changes in the names of streets and numbers of houses have been introduced in the list of addresses.
On sale at the leading Cairo and Alexandria booksellers.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
Hotel Dragomans in Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.

The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLUG.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1907
I BRITISH FLOUR FOR EGYPT.

4 In an article on Egypt's increasing importa tions of flour the "Miller” says : A short time ago we briefly commented upon the fact that although Egypt was importing larger quantities -of wheat flour every year the British

miller was not increasing his share of the trade in a corresponding ratio. Roughly speak-ing Egypt now takes over a million sack-yearly, and there is no apparent reason why the United Kingdom should not have a better showing against other countries, and especially against the French miller, who up to the present has had the lion's share of the trade with 700,000 sacks for last year compared with 70,000 sacks originating here. This is 10 to one in spotting parlance, and the odds are too long. It is quite true that our millers have doubled their quantity during last year seeing that in 1905 only 34.000 sacks were sent out, and there is nothing, or should be nothing, to prevent a still greater increase. The imports into Egypt of no other article

during the last two years show such a great increase as flour and grain of various sorts. Of course. we remember that opportunity served very well, seeing that those years were of the lean kind in Egypt, both wheat and maize being disappointing in yield ; but the opportunity must, or ought to, be followed up with increased assiduity in order to make the business a permanent one, remembering, also, that the population is constantly increasing and that cereal growing is giving place to cotton, which pays better. Besides that, the standard of living is rapidly being raised and new towns and industries are being established. We may also remember another thing Not long since one of the largest machinery orders ever given anywhere was secured by an English firm of flour milling engineers for a plant in South America, and the mill will very soon be at work. Behind that again yet another mill quite as large is to be built upon the most modern lines, to make flour for export to Europe. In the Argentine a powerful syndicate has come to the conclusion that it will be more profitable to export flour than wheat,and before long it will be doing it, so that we have one more reason for exhorting the home miller to get farther afield before the crush comes, to get established before the days of greater struggling begin to dawn It is a comparatively easy task to hold the homo fort in the top grades, but the medium and the residue are both likely to get more troublesome every year. The British palate is a mighty particular one in these days, and everything in flour below the top grade is unsuited to it, and wo single out Egypt and Scandinavia as typical countries where there ought to be a sufficient outlet for that residue, given the grit and push which is supposed to be characteristic of our mental and physical embodiment.
INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND IN ALEXANDRIA.

The Countess of Meath sends us the following communication : On various occasion* you have kindly promoted the cause of a most useful institution "The Industrial School for the Blind” in Alexandria. This establishment was one of those fortunate enough to be allowed to show its wares at the Agricultural Exhibition io Cairo opened this afternoon by H.H. the Khedive, who graciously visited the stall allotted to the Blind School, and thus gavo Lord Meath, who was present, an opportunity to toll his Highness that it was this institution winch first introduced European wicker work into Egypt This industry is now being taken up in several other establishments, and notably in Egyptian prisons It is much to be hoped that ciiminal labour - though in itaelf good for those engaged in it—will not be permitted to under sell that done by honest hands, and thus spoil the market. Five pupils from the Blind School at Alexandria wore present, and it is gratifying to find what skilful workmen they have become under the instruction of English teachers. One of the former attracted a good deal of notice by the ease with which he was reading and writing Traille type.

• This institution, unlike the interesting one established at Zeitoun, has never accepted an Egyptian Government grant, as it is the exclusive property of the Ministering Childrens League, a society started in England for the purpose of training children to lead unselfish lives and to take an active interest in the needs of the poor and suffering.

The Association has now the proud record of having initiated the foundation of 17 buildings devoted to charity in different parts of the world. Some of them are even found in distant Australasia, as in all four quarters of the globe this society has its branches. No than 32 centre* of work have been estab-
lished lately in Russia.

The Blind School in Alexandria has during the 8 or 9 years of its existence been fortunate enough to secure many friends but, it needs more who will kindly assist the blind in the best way, namely, by helping them to help
themselves.
A new teacher has lately come out from England, who will keep a good stock of wares in band, and will also gladly take orders for any special articles required to meet the needs of customers.

Shepherd's annual “Pita de Nnit" will be given on Friday. the 15th inat. Invitations will be issued shortly.
Military Tournament
The annual tournament of the Egyptian Army will ba held on the Observatory parade, ground, Abbassieh, on Thursday, 21st inst. postage to Asoenslon.
From 1st April next, the postage on letters from Egypt for Ascension Is and will be redacted and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.
Alhambra Theatre.
A Greek comedy company will make its debut at the Alhambra Theatre on the 20th inst. with an adaptation of the French vaudeville ‘ Lee Joiee da la Famille.”

'The Sudan Government has definitely decided to adhere to the lease system in the disposal of building sites at Port Sudan. The Government is quite satisfied with the result of the first auction which closed on the 1st January of this year.
Tour Eiffel Music Hall.

On Saturday night almost successful mankind bill was given at the Tour Eiffel Music Hall at Alexandria. The tickets for gentlemen were 100 francs each. The costumes were very fine and the greatest animation prevailed until 5 o’clock yesterday morning. The first prize was obtained by the first lady of the ballet at the Khedival Opera House Cairo.
Egyptian Hydraullo Stone Company, ltd.

This concern was registered 14th February. Capital £ 5,000 in £1 shares (5,000 "A" and 20,000 "B") Objects : To carry on the business of stone masons, builders, engineers, paviors, contractors, and to adopt an agreement with the United Egyptian Lands, Ltd. No initial public issue Registered office, Finsbury Pavement House, E.C.
Sudan Church Notes.

The second number of the "Sudan Church Notes" has now appeared. It is full of useful information about the church work during the month of January and an article, from the pen of the architect, on the revised plan of the Saints Church in Khartoum, extracts from which appear in this issue. In addition to the above this number contains some interesting sporting intelligence.
A Cinematograph Conflagration

Last evening at about 8 o'clock while the Cinematograph was being exhibited at the hall outside the Railway Terminus, the apparatus caught on fire. There was a large audience present, but they dispersed in an orderly manner and there was no stampede, The entire cinematographic apparatus and a small portion of the hall were burnt out. The damage to the machinery and films is estimated at from £300 to £100. The Alexandria Fire Brigade, under Yombashi Waller, was very prompt in arriving on the scene and within ten minutes of the call the fire was extinguished.
A Police Office notice states that in order to avoid the necessity of having to advance the hour for closing the despatch of registered correspondence, especially for abroad, banks

and commercial houres, having large quantities of such correspondence, are very earnestly requested to send as much as possible of it early to the poet, only keeping what is necessary to the last moment. This will give sufficient time for the completion of registration formalities and also avoid the delay to messengers now caused by the sudden and late arrival of a very large quantity of articles lor registration.

A very successful Fancy Dress-Ball was given by the above Alexandrian Benevolent Society at the Rooms of the French Artistic Union on Saturday evening. Masqueraders, were slow in arriving, but dancing commenced with a fair assembly at 10.15 p.m. By midnight the members had been considerably increased, and there were by this time some three to four hundred people present, with occasional parties still arriving These late comers were in some instances not fortunate enough to find them selves caught in the severe storm which passed over about 11 o’clock. The costumes were pretty and varied, the music good, a programme of 14 dances keeping the happy throng engaged until the morning hours. Altogether a very enjoyable evening was spent and what if the room was rather crowded, the atmosphere a trifle stuffy, and the evening really too warm for dancing, so long as is understood the fonds of the Society will be considerably bent fitted '

THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
EXTRAORDINARY DEMANDS
ANIMATED DISCUSSIONS

Yesterday’s meeting of the General Assembly was unprecedented for the animation with which the discussion of the many and various demands brought forward was carried on. The Assembly debated all the morning until midday and resumed its deliberation, in the afternoon at 8 o'clock and did not adjourn until late in the evening.
The resolutions proposing the enlargement of Tantah railway station and that the estates of interstate Moslems should be devoted to charitable purposes Were passed without opposition.

The greatest interest was shown in the pro-posal that the Arabic language should be the sole vehicle of instruction in all the Government schools, whether primary, secondary, or superior. Saad Pasha Zaghoula strongly opposed this measure in a most eloquent speech. Ha declared that neither the text books nor the teaching stuffs were available for <he purpose and he deprecated the resolution as premature and calculated to injure the cause of education in Egypt if it warn given effect to. In spite of his speech the resolution was carried with only five dissentients.

The most important resolution next discussed was that that full parliamentary institutions should be given to the Egyptian people, who should have entire control of the financial and other administrations. Pending the development of these institutions it was demanded that the powers of the Legislative Council should be largely increased.
This resolution was carried by a large majority.

A member who advocated the improvement and reform of the Wakfs Administration met with no support Another member, who proposed that free education should be guaranteed by a rate on land also met with no support
HONOUR FOR ANGLO- GYPTIAN.
(Gazette's Special Service. )
London Saturday.

At yesterday’s meeting of the Council of the Royal Society Dr. G Elliot Smith, M.D, CM, MA, the eminent Professor at the School of Medicine at Cairo, was nominated to a fellowship. This is considered a great honour for this Anglo Egyptian as since the late Professor Huxley was elected a fellow of the Royal Society fifty six years ago no anatomist has received the blue ribbon of British Science at the early age of 85 years.
ARMY OF OCCUPATION
THE EGYPTIAN COMMAND.
The following is the foil text of Mr Hal-me's statement on the forthcoming change in the Egyptian command. It is contained in customary memorandum of the Secretary
of State for Wars which accompanies the Army estimates of effective and non effective ser-
vices, which wire published a few days ago :

For many years the Commanders-in-Chief at Malta and Gibraltar have also been charged with the responsibilities of the civil government of those Colhuieas and it has been necessary to provide a complete staff, general, administrative, and personal, on a literal scale at each station. At the same time these two commands, as well as the third Mediterranean command of Egypt, have been entirely inde-
pendent of one another, without any provision co-ordination except through the War Office itself. In view of the progress
with decentralization from the War Office, it has been decided to appoint a purely military
Commander-in-Chief, with no civil duties, for the Mediterranean as a whole, to be stationed
Malta. No increase in cost of any kind will result from the new arrangements.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS
The Moss Liner “Menes" arrived yesterday morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails and a neral cargo.
The Moss Liner ''Busiris" sailed on Saturday afternoon, the 2nd inst, for Manchester via Malta, with mails and a general cargo, inclu-ding 385 bales and cotton.
The S.S. "Syrian Prince" with passengers and a general cargo left Manchester on the 1st, inst, end is due to arrive at Alexandria
on/or about the 17th inst.
The Canard S.S. Cypria is due here on the 7th. inst and will immediately begin loading cargo for Liverpool and American ports
The Ellerman Line Joshua Nicholson sailed this morning for Liverpool direct with age neral cargo including 3902 bales of Cotton.

AGRICULTURAL SHOW
ALLEN ALDERSON’S EXHIBITS

The first stand on the right, on entering the show ground, is occupied by Messr. Allen, Alderson and Company Limited, of Alexandria and Cairo, who exhibit a considerable number of interesting engines and machines. The pair of 20. H.P. ploughing engines. manufactured by Messra. John Fowler & Co. (Lead) Ltd. with their implements are conspicuously placed io front of thia stood, needless to say they are beautifully finished and in every respect among the leading article in this line. We understand that Mesars. Allen, Alderson and Company Limited had prepared three sets of tackle or this show, but both the 12 H P and 14 HP. set were sold a few days since and it was impossible to spare them for them time necessary for the show. Alongside these engines is one of Messrs. Ruston, Proctor and Co. Ltd. well known Tibbin-making trashing machines in motion. Here again we understand other machines possessing especially interesting features for Upper Egypt prepared for the show, bad to be delivered to buyers and were consequently lost for exhibition purposes. We were informed that last year Mesars Rustos, Proctor and Co. Limited made and delivered 986 thrashing machines in all, number which we believe has never been hasten as the production of one film in this line. The various portable steam and oil engines exhibited on tbit stand call for no special comment beyond the statement that they were all up to the usual standard of the makers. We were specially interested in the new pattern helical pumps by Messrs. Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited, of which quite a number were on show. These pumps are evidently great favorites, as we notice many of then on the stands of others makers being driven by various motor, and the "Ecola des Art et Metiers" have a beautifully finished model of one of them on their stand.

Messrs. Allen, Alderson and Company Limited, also show a very interesting deep lift centrifugal pump for wells 50 ft. deep, driven by a 5 HP. oil engine. This was designed for Upper Egypt, where there are hundreds of wells on which a sakieh was erected, irrigating about 5 to 6 feddans. The cattle plague stopped many of these and this small pump and engine was prepared to take the place of the rakiehs. It cannot fail to be a real boon to the man of small means. The same may be said of the 2. HP. oil engine and 8 helical pump on the same stand, which is a responding plant fur Lower Egypt. We cannot conclude this notice without alluding the 4 g HP. as suction plant and engine on this stand, this a beautiful piece of work, made by Raston, Proctor and CO. Limited, and we hear that Messrs. Allen, Alderton and Co. Limited have sold a considerable number of these, all of which are giving the utmost satis-faction, they are suitable for corn mills, centrifugal pumps, electric lighting and the hundreds of cases where a moderate amount of power is required, combined with the utmost economy. We were informed that the Aboukir Co. Ltd. has lately installed two of these with centrifugal pumps, on their estates near Ramleh, and were much pleased with them. Messrs. Allen. Alderson and Co. Limited have had a special and long experience in tbit line, as previous to Messrs Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited taking up the manufacture they erected a number of plants made by other continental films. We noticed a good show of Messrs F. Reddaway and Co. Ltd’s famous 'Camel" brand belting. This article has made its way all over the world and we need add little beyond stating that here as elsewhere we were told it was the belt of the future. In conclusion we may say that We were glad to see so good a show from the oldest firm in the machinery line in Egypt, as there is often too much of a disposition to rest on their lanrels long established businesses. Messrs. Alien, Alderson end Co. Limited show however that they mean to move with the time, and if possible keep a little ahead of it.
ARTHUR KOPPEL LTD.

This well known firm of world-wide repulsion has exhibited a number of very interesting specimens of railway material of every description. . We especially noticed a complete installation of light railway plant, in connection with steel tipping wagons drawn by a locomotive of 600 m/fn gauge, the working of which was much admired. Among other items of interest our attention was called to' light and heavy tails and sleepers of various section points, and crossings, turntables, wheels and axles. Axelboxes and different types of platforms and engine wagons used on light railways. All the trucks bearing the mark "Arthur Koppel" combining lightness with strength and durability are of the latest design, filled with special patent roller bearings" which give a great saving of hauling power. We can therefore highly recommend Messrs. Arthur Koppels plant to all cultivators, industrial and contractors of this country, which will surely find this material of greet value for their respective work.

CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA*
THE “EGYPTIAN STANDARD”
NEW NATIONALIST ORGAN
THE INAUGURAL TEA

At 5 o'clock on. Saturday afternoon the solemn inaugural ceremony of a five o'clock tea to other in the "Egyptian Standard” and ''L'Etendard Egyptian" took place at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo. All the Egyptian followers of Mostapha Pasha Kamel mastered in force, and the entire "Nationalist Party” were assembled in the Arabic Hall nf the hotel, which consequently was almost full of people. The first speech was delivered by the Praha. We need not deal with the speech of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, for his statements never vary and whether he is writing to * Le Tempe* or the "Figaro"or contributing to his own vernacular organ his speeches contain but a single theme concealed amidst floods of verbosity. It is needless therefore to inform our readers that he again dilated with impassioned eloquence on his great war cry of "Carthago eat delenda" and after speaking on this topic for a considerable time sat down amidst the enthusiastic plaudits of his audience.
Next came the French editor of "L'Etenard Egyptian."
M. Saint Ogan's discourse was embellished with some remarkable historical allusions. We extract the following from the exordium: Gentleman :

In the eighteenth century and under the ministry of Fleny France remained inactive in presence of the Russian menace against Poland. Fired with indignation, a Frenchman, the Count of Pelo, wished to save his country's honor. He put himself at the head of a body of his compatriots and. without instructions of any kind, obeying simply a generous impulse, endeavoured to carry assistance to the beleaguered ’own of Danzig.
I compare the group of Frenchmen who compose the editorial staff of L'Eteadara Egyption with the above small army.
In hie peroration he invokes the Handled Years' War:
The ornel and undeserved ordeal of the English Occupation is only a short episode.
the new paper under the Pacha's direction.
We need not give Mr. Rudy's speech in fall. The following preliminary remarks of that gentleman will suffice:

Gentlemen.— It will necessary for me to explain to you Mr. Maloney's and my presence among you here today, the reason why we have come to Cairo to work under Monataf, Kamel Pasha's guidance on the editorial staff of "The Egyptian Standard."

Before our arrival we heard and read about the foreign autocratic government which is endeavoring to throttle Egyptian independence. We learnt how it had come to the Nile Valey to advise the Egyptian Government, to re-tore order before leaving and to teach the people how to govern themselves. We had read about treaties signed in the name of the British nation, and promises made by talesmen in the name of the British nation. These treaties and promises have proved to be empty, however; they were looked upon as worthless sheets of papers and hollow word , involving the honor and dignity of no nation. We were surprised, Mr. Manoley and I, at this disregard for a given word. We could not understand it. Surely statesmen and signatories —all of them British—could bear their own try no such ill-will as to cause her name to be looked at askance abroad For was not England one of the bulwarks of progress and civilization? Was she not a free nation? How could she then tyrannize over a foreign people, a country which was neither a colony nor a protecto rate, but a friend? I repeat it, gentlemen, we could not understand it? We were surprised to learn the ins and outs of certain happenings in the Nile Valley; some even disgusted us when the gold palm with which they bad been disguised wore off etc., etc.
After Mr. Rudy had finished the Pasha made another long speech and then antes, "a 'anglaise" be it noted, was served and success to the new papers was drank in tea.

The "Egyptian Standard" made its first appearance yesterday morning.' It contains a number of articles all written in the style, which the anglophobe vernacular Press has made ns acquainted with for years past with the sole difference that English and not Arabic is the medium.

SPORT AND PLAY
The final of the Big Unit Shield was played at Ghezireh on the 2nd inst., amidst great

and the football of a high standard, the Dublins were quicker on the ball, their left forward, being especially conspicuous, for pace and brilliant play. Lieut. Crozier also, outside left, was very round and safe. The first goal to the Dublin, the Guard’, gnat keeper was
caught napping, and the same may be said for the Dublins, when the Guards scored their one and only goal. The judgement displayed by
the Rev. Anderson as referee was highly com-
KHARTOUM AGRICULTURAL SHOW

The fifth Annual Agricultural and Industrial how of Khartoum Province was held in the Public Gardens last week, under the patronage of His Excellency the Governor General. A large number of exhibits were displayed in the usual manner.

In the morning, the exhibits were examined by the committee of judges, and prizes were awarded. In the afternoon the gardens were opened to the public, who came in large numbers. The weather was fine, and the music furnished by the band of the King's Rifles added considerably to the enjoyment of all present. The Governor General and Lady Wingate visited the exhibition at 4.20 p.m. They were received at the entrance by Miralai Stanton Bey and the Mamur of Khartoum. His Excellency was much pleased with the exhibition and expressed his satisfaction to the Governor.

At 5 o'clock refreshments were served at the refreshment pavilion. The Governor entertained those that contributed to the prize fund, to tea and refreshments. His Excellency left the gardens at 6 p.m. after which prizes in cash and in the shape of fancy silver article, were distributed among the successful exhibitors.

The success of the exhibition is in large measure due to the energy and interest of Miralai Stanton Bey, tue Governor of the Pro-vince, who was aided by his able staff of officers and officials. On the whole, the exhibition was decidedly in advance of that of last year. With the exception of the silverware department, the industrial section did not make much advance. No carpentry work was exhibited except a number of articles made at the Prison, and as we are told, not especially designed fur the exhibition. The Gordon College Workshops could certainly have sent a creditable exhibit of carpentry work done by their pupils. The first prize for Angarebs was awarded for an angareb of Zan wood, made in the, shape of a European bedstead, and carved in a rather bizarre fashion. Measra. Dilaveri exhibited a fine collection of osment pavement The agricultural section was certainly in advance of former exhibition, The cotton samples were of very fine quality, much superior to anything hitherto seen. The vegetable collections attracted much attention. There is no doubt but that market gardening would be quite profitable in this country, if well taken in hand, and would supply an important need. Very fine collection of grain of last year's crop were exhibited. On the whole, says the "Sudan Times” the improvement is quite marked though the agricultural section tedious, more of it than the industrial The evidence is clear that the Government is putting forth every reasonable effort to develop the resources, of the country, and by such exhibitions is encouraging Agriculture and Industry, and leading the country forward to a grand destiny.
